title: Add Facebook Open Graph and Twitter Cards metadata
body: This PR adds some basic Open Graph and Twitter Cards metadata to each page. I make a distinction here between the index page and documents (i.e. material in `/docs`). Metadata that applies to all pages is templated in `layouts/partials/meta.ace` and supplied via the `params` in `config.yaml`; metadata that only applies to the index page is templated in `layouts/partials/index/index-meta.ace`; and metadata for documents is templated in `layouts/partials/docs/page-meta.ace`.

title: Fix Heron build date locale
body:
This PR forcibly sets the date output to be in English. As my default locale is not English, I was getting a corrupted `release.yaml` file and thus was getting errors when trying to run an example topology:

```
 heron submit local ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar com.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology ExclamationTopology
INFO: Launching topology 'ExclamationTopology'
Exception in thread "main" unacceptable character '^G' (0x87) special characters are not allowed
in "'reader'", position 45
    at org.yaml.snakeyaml.reader.StreamReader.checkPrintable(StreamReader.java:93)
    at org.yaml.snakeyaml.reader.StreamReader.update(StreamReader.java:192)

    at org.yaml.snakeyaml.Yaml.load(Yaml.java:381)

It's incomplete but it provides a scaffolding that can be used by later contributors to produce a more fully fleshed out Javadocs landing page. Here's the existing site: Here's the site with the placeholder material added in this PR: **Note**: This branch was originally created out of the branch behind PR #798. This may produce merge issues down the line.

title: Temporary solution to Javadocs issue (#797)
body:
I'm not particularly fond of this solution and I hope that we can find a better one, but this is _a_ solution that eliminates some unpleasant surprises for new users and seems to have very few potential downsides. Some background:
- As far as I can tell, in order to view the Javadocs locally when running `make serve` (which starts up the Hugo server to view the docs locally), they need to be in the `website/static` directory. This is important for developing the docs, fixing links, etc.
- But if the Javadocs are in `website/static` and not in `website/public`  then they can't be published to the `gh-pages` branch (and thus cannot go live on the site).
- Having the Javadocs in both locations provides a solution but it's not [DRY](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself) and feels kind of janky

Suggestions welcome!

title: Fix pip-related issues in website setup script
body:
`make setup` is currently causing `pip`-related issues regarding permissions. This PR _should_ help to alleviate those issues (please let me know if this does not work on your machine).

If your dev environment for the website is currently broken (perhaps due to past setup scripts), I would recommend uninstalling and then re-installing `pip` before running `make setup` again:

``` bash
# If pip is still working
pip freeze | xargs sudo -H pip uninstall -y
sudo -H pip uninstall pip -y
# Do all of the below whether or not pip is working
sudo rm -rf ~/Library/Caches/pip
sudo rm -rf /Library/Python/2.7/site-packages
curl -O https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py
python get-pip.py
sudo chown -R $USER ~/Library/Logs/pip
sudo chown -R $USER ~/Library/Caches/pip
rm get-pip.py
cd /path/to/heron/website
make setup
```

title: Revert adding generics to Storm APIs
body:
Fixed #692 by reverting addition of generics from the apache and backtype storm API.

Adding generics was a noble effort, and it would have worked with Java, but it fails with scala, which is more strict with types. We still have generics in Heron and users will need to add them if they migrate completely to the Heron APIs, but if they write to the Storm API they can run on both Storm and Heron.

I've tested this locally with scala classes that I've manaully built against a heron-storm.jar built with this patch.. Would like to get those tests into the repo somehow but we don't yet support scala builds.

title: General website cleanup
body:
This PR accomplishes a few (minor and non-blocking) things for the website:
- Adds a `dev-assets` command to the `Makefile` to make it easier to work on static assets
- Moves the `javadocs` and `linkchecker` scripts to a separate `scripts` folder (for the sake of tidying up the root `website` folder a bit)
- Completes the `nvm` installation instructions for Mac OS X
- Renames the `src` folder to the more intuitive `assets`
- Unzips the `heron-logos.zip` file and places all the unzipped images in `assets/img/heron-logos`
- Updates the website `README` to reflect all of these changes

title: Fix of doc generation.
body:
This PR fixes all the errors during doc generation, but with 100 warnings left. Those warnings are emitted **all** because `javadoc` transitively builds doc and cannot find doc for Google's Protobuf library. 

Specifically, this PR
1. deleted `/contrib`
2. fixed Java documentation usage (`>` changes to `>`, `&` changes to `&`, and etc)
3. updated `javadocs.sh` to include doc generation for generated Java files that interact with Protobuf API (for example, `TopologyContext.java`) . Docs for them are useful to Heron's developers.

Note: one can only merge this PR when all warnings are gone, which needs more time.

title: fix scheduler location
body:
1. Aurora scheduler runs as a lib instead of a service.
2. Setting schedulerlocation node as ephemeral node results the heron-ui/heron-tracker cannot get any data for the scheduler location. The reason is when the seesion is ended, all data under a ephemeral node is deleted.
3. Now we separate the scheduler as service and scheduler as lib cases. For the service case, we create ephemeral node for scheduler location; For the lib case, we create normal znode for scheduler location
